There's an interesting theory that increases in volcanic activity may be indirectly caused by decreases in solar activity, hence causing cooling.


Basically when solar activity decreases, the Sun's magnetosphere (which extends~250 AU beyond the Sun) weakens.


This in tern allows large amount of Cosmic rays to enter out solar system.


These cosmic rays are extremely energetic and can pierce several miles below the Earth's surface, and are mostly absorbed by the liquid or semi-solid silicon below the Earth's surface.


This heats up the silicon, hence increasing convection currents and hence increasing volcanic and tectonic activity.


NASA, Harvard, along with numerous other institutes have found and acknowledged this negative correlation between Solar activity and volcanic activity (especially silicon rich volcanic activity).

I think a lot of the change we are seeing today is based on the fact that we are moving out of the Little Ice Age and moving into another Warm Period. Yes humans are compounding the problem with carbon and methane emissions etc but I think it is also because it is just part of nature. We always experience Little Ice Ages and Warm Periods and go back and forth between the two. But we haven't had super accurate temperature records over the last 2,000 years and we are used to the "cooler" temperatures of the times of the Little Ice Age and the in-between periods, which is where we have been over the last 300 years or so and now we are moving more and more into this warm period. But we do not remember the last time we was in a Warm Period because that happened in the Medieval times, from 950-1250.

Then there was a fluxing period in-between for 50-100 years and then there was the Little Ice Age from 1350-1850.... then there was another 100 year flux that we lived in and are used to, but we are now moving further into another 300 year Warm Period and everyone is freaking out. In short, we are probably assigning too much blame on human activity because humans like to think we are number 1 at everything, including destroying the planet. Temperatures will likely rise for the next 100 years, then they will level off over the next 100, and then start to drop again 100 years after this. So by 2200 we will be back to the same temperatures we were used to pre-1990's. Then we will pat each other on the back thinking we curtailed global warming by cutting CO2 emissions by 10% over a 300 year period.

Ugh, the "general crisis". At least you put it in a more sensible timeframe – the troubled years 1620-60 – rather than dragging it out to 1720 or even 1740 when prices pick up. But when wasn’t much of Europe plagued by hunger, war or rebellion (or plague)? 1520-60 was hardly a time of peace either (German peasant and religious wars, Valois vs Habsburgs in Italy, Habsburgs vs Ottomans in Hungary, uprisings in England, coups in Scotland), or 1420-60 (last phase of the Hundred Years War, the Hussite war in Bohemia, fall of Constantinople, the Thirteen Years war in Prussia – we’re going to use up all the multiples of years eventually). As for 1320-60, the less said the better: now that’s a general crisis.

China of course had it especially bad in the century’s middle decades, as did Germany in the second quarter and Poland in the third, but Europe’s trade with Asia surged to 1680 after slumping in 1620-40, when we might expect it to have languished in the doldrums throughout. The commercially-sensitive business capitals of London and Amsterdam added 200,000 between them, and Lisbon, Nantes and Stockholm shared in the good times: even Dublin grew amid successive national traumas. Away with this "general crisis"! There were crises aplenty, but none was "general". We might as well speak of a "general crisis" of conflict, instability, famine and disease extending from the Bronze Age to the 20th century.

I don’t know where that claim about half of Scots men (that’s around 150,000 people) emigrating in the first half the 17th century comes from: it sounds a bit over the top to me. There were many Scots on the Continent, it’s true – as many as 50,000 of them fighting in the 30 Years War (many of whom doubtless returned to relate their adventures), perhaps a similar number (including some of the same former soldiers) engaged in trade, others just fleeing hunger at home, notably in the 1620s – and doubtless a good number in England (besides the odd military foray into England or Ireland). But the Plantation of Ulster was a rather slow affair until the "ill years" of the 1690s (when something of the order of 50,000 moved), and emigration to the Americas only took off from the 1760s. A third seems more probable allowing for double-counting, returnees and a bit of exaggeration by disgruntled locals.

'Climate Change', 'Climate Fluctuations', 'Global Warming/Global Cooling Cycles', heat wave, ice age, whatever you want to call it is nothing new. These are just natural phenomena that have far more to do with our source of global warmth than anything that we do here on our great planet. I'm certainly not proposing that we cease our global efforts to improve the usage of our planet's resources. Actually I feel quite the opposite. I am just saying that it does not always have to be an all or nothing approach. Some fuel types obviously are more economical and more readily available in some areas than others, and to expect the entire planet to adopt the same energy agenda is very narrow minded and ridiculous, especially for underdeveloped countries.

Solar cycles come and go, and may be decades or centuries in length. The real thing to be concerned about is solar storms or flares that with relatively little warning could wipe out so much of the technology that we are becoming increasingly dependent upon in the high tech regions of the world. For more information about this, you should refer to a real scientist (rather than a political pawn or socialist idiot). Look for someone who studies the empirical evidence alone. Look for someone who studies as many factors as possible and let's the evidence speak for itself instead of starting with a preconceived idea and then finds partial evidence to support that view. oh come on CC. Vet your data once in a while.

It only took like 10 minutes of scholarly searching to find that...

Dendrochronology is only accurate if you already KNOW the factors you are testing for. If you are trying to get data OTHER than the date, then you are testing for variance, hence, you are not getting a date more accurate than about 40-50 years depending on how far back you are going.

Ice core samples are even MORE variant. At best you could tell mean temperature change within 2-5C with a range of 50-200 YEARS.

That kind of data might be fine for making statements about how mean temperatures from 1500-2000 compare to 10k years ago, but they are nowhere near precise enough to prove your case.

Barring a nuclear or biological event, it is near impossible to PROVE that climate change is not natural, or even occurring within a single human lifetime. There are so many factors involved in weather/climate. We just don't have the width OR the depth of data needed to make these statement.

DISCLAIMER: I do believe that we are destroying the environment that we rely on to survive as a species. We have a bad habit of just dumping things into the atmosphere because it is convenient. I also believe that we probably ARE having some sort of effect on the global climate, and that we need to stop because we don't actually know HOW bad we might be making it for our descendants. But this does not mean we can actually PROVE that this is happening with such a small sample size.

In which @John Green teaches you about the Little Ice Age. The Little Ice Age was a period of global cooling that occurred from the 13th to the 19th centuries. This cooling was likely caused by a number of factors, including unusual solar activity and volcanic eruptions. The Little Ice Age greatly  impacted human social orders, especially during the 17th century. When the climate changed, and weather became unpredictable, the world changed profoundly. Poor harvests led to hunger, which led to even less productivity, which even resulted in violent upheaval in a lot of places. All this from a little change in the temperature? Definitely.

A note on the sunspots theory: during the 1600's, the sun went through a grand minimum in its sunspot cycles. This means that basically a couple sunspot cycles in a row were essentially missing for 70 years. The cycles didn't completely go away, but they were very, very significantly weaker and had much less sunspots during that period.

Also, during this period of global warming we've been in the past century, sunspot cycles have been significantly stronger, with a decline similar to the early 1600's decline happening in recent years. This suggests that we may be approaching another grand minimum in the sunspot cycles.

(8:29) Erm when you said that half of the adult Scottish population emigrated in the early 17th century, I don't think that is correct. Around 11% of the population emigrated in the 1690's, but the mass emigration of Scottish people didn't happen until the lowland and highland clearances in the late 18th to the early 19th century, by which they were forcibly removed to make way for wool producing sheep during the agricultural revolution. So technically, Scots did not emigrate during the little ice age. Also the small amount of people who did emigrate during the little ice age, didn't stay, but returned to Scotland in the early 18th century.

So question. after 15 minutes on the internet, I found these little gems. http://www.carbonbrief.org/blog/2013/11/solar-activity-and-the-so-called-%E2%80%9Clittle-ice-age%E2%80%9D/ This one refutes the whole sunspot theory that CrashCourse proposed. 4:05

And this one, http://www.forbes.com/sites/jamestaylor/2011/07/27/new-nasa-data-blow-gaping-hold-in-global-warming-alarmism/ This talks about about NASA temperature data that shows that the Earth is radiating more heat then the UN's global warming computer models predicted.

Yes climate change is happening, but we need to be discussing the REAL data that the world's scientists are gathering, especially not leaving out any information that might contradict the ''official'' party line.

For solutions to climate change, these are my favorite:
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iron_fertilization This deals with CO2 concentrations that is a cause of worry.
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sunshade This deals with temperature problems that the Earth has.

Either of these solutions would cost a lot of money yes, but these are doable concrete solutions to climate problems that don't cripple the world's economy and industry, i.e. carbon taxes, gas taxes, EPA regulations, airline taxes, etc.
